28.08.text: Hello. Tonight sees the first match

30.72.text: of our short seasonal contest for alumni of some of

34.60.text: the UK's leading universities and university colleges.

37.12.text: No doubt it seemed like a good idea at the time when 14 teams

40.48.text: agreed to try to uphold the dignity of their institution,

43.68.text: and ten matches from now, one of them will be crowned series champion.

47.44.text: Their prize will be nothing more than the honour of victory,

50.64.text: to be savoured over the last of the mince pies and a glass from

54.44.text: the bottle of medium sherry that last year's winners didn't quite finish.

58.36.text: There are only two rules for taking part.

60.56.text: Players must have graduated from the institution they represent,

64.00.text: and since then, they must have made something of their careers.

67.32.text: As we will see, the second rule is applied pretty loosely.

70.68.text: With 14 teams competing, there will be

72.52.text: seven winners in the first round,

74.36.text: but only the four teams with the highest winning scores

79.28.text: The rest can carry on with their Christmases without this

84.84.text: Now, first, the team from University College London.

87.84.text: It's a constituent college of the Federal University of London,

93.20.text: As well as being a graduate,

94.80.text: their first player was former vice-chair of the UCL Council.

99.60.text: she has written for such authoritative publications

102.32.text: as the Journal of Molecular Biology

104.68.text: and The News of the World, and also works at Genomics England,

108.40.text: involved in the sequencing of DNA.

110.56.text: With her, another expert in genomics, having presented

114.00.text: a television documentary on that subject and many others.

117.08.text: He has also contributed to that festive tome

121.80.text: Their captain is one of the nation's sternest grammar disciplinarians

125.72.text: and the author of Eats, Shoots and Leaves.

128.52.text: She's a broadcaster, playwright and columnist.

132.72.text: He has written for the Guardian for the past decade,

135.16.text: as well as for The Times,

137.00.text: and has presented numerous television programmes,

139.40.text: including one professing his lonely passion for brutalist architecture.

145.24.text: Hello, I'm Vivienne Parry, I graduated in zoology

148.64.text: from London University and I majored in immunology and genetics at UCL.

153.40.text: And now I'm a writer and broadcaster.

156.68.text: I'm Adam Rutherford, and I read genetics at UCL from 1993

160.76.text: until 2002, including my PhD on the development of the eye.

164.60.text: Now I'm a writer and broadcaster.

166.96.text: I present Inside Science for BBC Radio 4.

171.40.text: Hello, I'm Lynne Truss, I graduated in English from UCL in 1977

176.24.text: and I am now a writer.

178.52.text: Hello, I'm Tom Dyckhoff, I did

180.32.text: an MA in architectural history at UCL in the mid-1990s.

183.88.text: Now I am a critic, writer and broadcaster

192.52.text: Playing them, a team from the University of Birmingham,

198.32.text: and occupying a site in Edgbaston.

200.56.text: We could be forgiven for thinking that their first player is

203.16.text: a scientist, given that she shares her surname with her distinguished

206.60.text: great-great-grandfather. Instead, she has chosen the path of the arts.

211.44.text: Her colleague reported for Fox FM, Sky News

214.20.text: and Central Television before joining BBC News 24 in 1999,

218.16.text: since when she has also turned her hand to writing.

221.20.text: Anyone who has ever got drenched because they left home without

224.32.text: their mackintosh will be delighted to see that the Birmingham captain

227.60.text: is a television weather presenter who claims that the forecast

230.60.text: is always right, it's the weather that sometimes goes wrong.

233.76.text: Finally, a gold medallist at the 2012 London Paralympic Games,

237.60.text: who is interrupting her training for the 2016 Rio Paralympics to

241.64.text: give her brain cells a workout.

246.32.text: Hello, I'm Emma Darwin, I graduated in drama and theatre arts

249.60.text: from Birmingham in the 1980s and I now write novels and non-fiction.

254.72.text: Hello, I'm Joanna Gosling, I graduated

256.96.text: from Birmingham University with a degree in French in 1993.

260.20.text: I'm now a BBC news presenter and author.

262.92.text:
- This is their captain. 
- Hi, I'm John Hammond.

265.28.text: I completed a Masters in meteorology from Birmingham in 1989.

269.44.text: I'm now a BBC weather presenter.

272.36.text: Hi, I'm Pamela Relph, I graduated in 2011 with a degree in physics

277.08.text: and now I am an athlete on the GB Rowing Team.

285.76.text: OK, I will remind you all of the rules.

287.88.text: There are ten points for starter questions,

290.00.text: which you must answer on the buzzer, on your own, with no conferring.

293.44.text: Each correctly answered starter earns the team a set of

296.96.text: bonus questions worth a possible 15 points.

299.52.text: For these, the team can and should confer,

302.00.text: with the captain giving the answer.

304.20.text: There being 14 teams, there are seven first-round matches,

307.72.text: but only the four winning teams with the high scores will

311.48.text: go through to the next stage, so my advice is - get on with it.

315.32.text: Fingers on the buzzers, here is your first starter for ten.

318.44.text: For many years, the annual Christmas carol concerts at Broadstairs

321.84.text: in Kent where conducted by which political figure born there in...?

327.84.text: No, I'm afraid you lose five points.

330.32.text: You could have heard the rest,

332.00.text: but as you buzzed, you have to give the answer.

334.44.text:
- Ted Heath. 
- It was Ted Heath. Yes, indeed.

337.52.text: So you get the first set of bonuses, UCL.

340.44.text: They are on the recipe for Nigella Lawson's Ultimate Christmas Pudding

344.08.text: according to her website. I want you to name the ingredients in each case.

348.20.text: Firstly, for five points, made from the grape grown in Andalusia,

352.72.text: a dark variety of sherry used to soak the dried fruits for the pudding.

357.12.text: According to Lawson, it has a hint of liquorice, fig and treacle about it.

361.76.text:
- Is that Pedro Ximenez? 
- What? 
- Is it?

365.28.text: It could be Pedro Ximenez sherry.

369.92.text: We think it's sherry, but could it be Pedro Ximenez sherry?

372.80.text: It IS Pedro Ximenez sherry, yes.

375.36.text: Secondly, a dark brown unrefined sugar extracted from cane sugar

379.40.text: and having the flavour of molasses.

381.32.text: Its name ultimately derives from the Spanish meaning "of poor quality".

385.88.text:
- Is that what it means? 
- Demerara? 
- Oh, that might be.

391.64.text: It means "of poor quality" in Spanish.

394.84.text: Muscovado sounds like it's from Moscow.

400.80.text: And finally, a hard white fat taken from the region around the loins

404.88.text: and kidneys of animals such as cattle and sheep.

410.88.text: Ten points at stake for this starter question, fingers on the buzzers.

415.08.text: Which political song was first published

421.88.text: Written by the Irish political activist Jim Connell,

425.20.text: it has historically been associated with the socialist movement.

428.72.text:
- Red Flag. 
- The Red Flag is correct, yes.

434.28.text: Right, these bonuses are on the Royal Institution Christmas Lectures.

437.72.text: Firstly, for five, who delivered the 1937 lecture series entitled

441.32.text: Rare Animals and the Disappearance of Wildlife?

445.68.text: he is particularly associated with the field of evolutionary biology.

449.48.text:
- Could it be Huxley? 
- Could be...

457.28.text:
- Huxley, could it be Huxley? 
- Which Huxley though?

465.80.text:
- A Huxley, yes, not specific enough. 
- Julian Huxley. 
- It's Julian Huxley.

468.88.text: I'm sorry, you were too late.

471.52.text: And secondly, who was the Christmas lecturer in 1964,

474.52.text: delivering a series with the title Animal Behaviour?

477.48.text: His later books include The Human Zoo and The Human Animal.

482.64.text: Correct. Finally, who was the lecturer in 1973

485.12.text: with a series entitled The Language of Animals?

489.32.text:
- Tim Bergen. 
- Bergen, I don't know him. 
- Or it might be Dawkins.

494.76.text: Language of animals, who do you think? '73.

500.28.text:
- (Dr Dolittle.) 
- Go with Tim. 
- Tim... 
- Bergen.

509.08.text: Right, ten points for this, fingers on your buzzers.

511.36.text: A ladder with its top rung five metres from its base is

515.28.text: placed on horizontal ground living against a perfectly vertical

518.76.text: Christmas tree growing in a field.

521.16.text: The foot of the ladder is three metres from the tree -

523.64.text: how many metres up the tree does the top rung reach?

528.60.text: Of course it is. Yes, it's Pythagoras.

535.28.text: Right, UCL, your bonuses are on 20th century political figures

538.40.text: as described in obituaries in The Times.

542.56.text: "Much that he did was memorable, very little that he said."

546.64.text: These words refer to which British Prime Minister who died in 1967?

563.24.text:
- No, it is Clement Attlee. 
- Oh, you said that.

565.68.text: "Neither his colleagues nor the Chinese people could

568.24.text: "share his absolute dedication to eternal struggle

572.60.text: These words appear in the 1976 obituary of which national leader?

581.96.text: In a 1999 obituary, who was described as "a person of considerable

585.64.text: "ability and charm in her own right who helped to give a human face

598.44.text:
- Gorbachev's wife? 
- Is it someone's wife? 
- Gorbachev's wife.

610.64.text: Maybe you will get going with this picture round.

612.80.text: You going to see a map with

616.32.text: For ten points, I want you to tell me

617.88.text: the name of the politician who

619.96.text: lost his seat there in May 2015?

627.16.text: No, anyone want to buzz from Birmingham?

634.96.text: Rather shaming, in a news presenter, that, isn't it?

638.76.text: We are going to take the picture bonuses in a moment or two

641.68.text: when someone gets a starter question right.

644.72.text: Firstly, for 10 points, the former civil servant Millvina Dean,

658.76.text: which she experienced as a two-month-old...?

661.84.text:
- Titanic.

668.16.text: Right, you'll be pleased to hear that you get more

671.40.text: picture questions on general election scalps.

677.76.text: previous parliament, was the most senior politician in Scotland

685.84.text: the biggest scalps of that election were taken.

688.04.text: Again, in each case I want you to tell me

690.08.text: the name of the politician who lost their seat there, please.

708.36.text: Well, he was a bit of a brief flash, wasn't he, old Vince Cable?

711.68.text:
- Ah!

716.52.text: That's Liverpool, yes. That's the Wirral.

722.56.text: It will be Labour, probably. Em...

733.72.text: who was an employment minister in the last government.

736.24.text: That was Wirral West. Finally, whose seat was this?

741.96.text: It was Ed Balls! Yes, congratulations.

745.92.text: Right, ten points for the starter question.

747.84.text: Which ballet did the US critic Sarah Kaufman described in 2009 as

752.32.text: "a chore", suggesting that each year it casts its long shadow...

762.00.text: You get a set of bonuses, Birmingham, on sea birds.

772.72.text: The largest member of the family was hunted to extinction

779.52.text: The albatross is the extinction, I think they are all gulls.

790.76.text: They often feed by harassing other birds

801.88.text: are among species of which migratory bird?

804.64.text: The last of these is found from the Arctic to the Antarctic.

817.32.text: Ten points for this. Its bark used in tannin

819.80.text: and its resin as a source of turpentine,

821.80.text: which three in the pine family is unusual in being

827.12.text: differing in the latter respect from coniferous evergreens

829.76.text: such as the fir, the cedar and the spruce?

- No idea.

876.40.text: Correct. In the 1986 work Dawn of the Gods,

881.64.text: may have been a matriarchy despite its name

885.28.text: deriving from that of a legendary king?

894.28.text:
- Matriarchy... 
- After a famous king. 
- After a famous king.

901.84.text: It's the Minoan. Ten points for this.

903.52.text: Meanings of what four-letter word include a tuft, tress

906.24.text: or ringlet of hair, a hold in wrestling or martial arts...?

916.68.text: These bonuses are on Nobel prizes awarded in 2015.

939.28.text: one recipient being Tu Youyou for her discoveries concerning

960.92.text: their existence was first postulated by Pauli in 1931.

996.52.text: 'On a branch of a big tree sat a little bird - Peter's friend.

1001.48.text: '"All is quiet - all is quiet," chirped the bird, gaily.'

1016.76.text: No. Anyone like to buzz from UCL? Quickly.

1098.24.text: 'They argued and argued, the duck swimming in the pond,

1114.56.text:

1268.60.text: No, there are two Ss as well. LAUGHTER AND GROANS

1653.64.text: which film directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu...

1666.84.text: Well, you never really got a chance to get going, did you, Birmingham?

1669.80.text: But thank you very much for joining us.

1671.48.text: UCL, the four highest-scoring winners come back, so, who knows?

1675.44.text: You might be one of the four highest scores,

1677.48.text:
- in which case, we shall look forward to seeing you again.

1680.44.text: Until the next time, when we'll have another first round match,

1688.96.text:
- ALL:
